body_content.explanation: used to refer to a computer that can operate on its own, without being connected to a network (= a number of computers connected together):
examples: At first personal computers were standalone units on employees' desks.
These concerns are particularly important when searches involve complicated computer networks (as opposed to stand-alone PCs ).

body_content.explanation: used to refer to electronic equipment that exists as a single device, rather than being combined in another device:
examples: Small or home offices often don't have space for stand-alone printers, scanners, fax machines, or copiers, so they end up with a multifunction device.
With standalone DVD recorders, media speed is less critical, since you record television in real time.

body_content.explanation: used to refer to computer software that works on its own, with no help from the internet or any other computer process:
examples: An end-user application is stand-alone software that installs directly on the user's system.
Some of the apps are inferior versions of the company's standalone programs.

body_content.explanation: used to refer to a business or organization that is not part of a larger one:
examples: Baylor is one of only nine stand-alone medical schools in the United States.
The move would break up the firm, leaving its corporate consultancy as a standalone entity.

body_content.explanation: used to refer to something that is not part of a set or series (= a set of books, broadcasts, films , etc. on the same subject or using the same characters):
examples: He has written a few stand-alone novels and a couple of series.
